text.b: AGENDA FOR THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES

page.text: Report on Assault Weapons Ban and HB183 Firearm Concealed Carry Act

C-2 Outlying Commercial District, Amending the Comprehensive Plan and Approving a Special Use for
Ordinance Approving Variation Requests at 780 Saunders Road to Allow For Construction of a

Referral of Commercial Lease Tax Concept to Northwest Municipal Conference
Authorization to Purchase a Traffic Sign Management System and Retro - Reflectivity Analysis
Authorization to Execute IUOE Local 150 Collective Bargaining Agreement Extension
Items for discussion by Mayor and Board of Trustees
The regular meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Village of Deerfield was called to
order by Mayor Rosenthal in the Council Chambers of the Village Hall on June 3 at 7:30 p.m.
The Clerk called the roll and announced that the following were:
and that a quorum was present and in attendance. Also present were Village Attorney Peter
Coblentz and Kent Street, Village Manager.
Cub scouts from pack 450 led those in attendance in
reciting the Pledge of Allegiance. Pack leader
Lydia St. John thanked the Village. She reported they entered into a partnership with the
American Legion and will have a community service project on June 12, 2013. The scouts will
be collecting old flags for the American Legion to retire.
Trustee Struthers reminded residents that mosquito season has started. She reminded everyone
to mitigate any standing water. She encouraged residents to call the South Lake Mosquito
Abatement District hotline with any questions or concerns.
Trustee Struthers moved approval of the minutes
from the May 20, 2012 Board of Trustees meeting.
Trustee Benton seconded the motion. The motion passed unanimously.
Trustee Benton moved approval of the minutes from the May 13, 2012 Committee of the Whole
meeting. Trustee Struthers seconded the motion. The motion passed unanimously.
Trustee Seiden moved approval of the bills and
Payroll dated June 3, 2013. Trustee Jester seconded
the motion. The motion passed by the following vote:
Brit Weinstein, 1513 Dartmouth Lane, is a second
grade student. He suggested building a pedestrian
underpass at Wilmot and Deerfield Roads to make it safer when residents walk to South Park and
Caruso schools. He noted kids would also be able to walk to the pool if there were an underpass.
Mayor Rosenthal thanked Mr. Weinstein for coming to speak to the Board and stated that the
issue would be discussed during the coming budget season.
The Plan Commission held a Public Hearing on
May 9, 2013, to consider the request for an
REQUEST FOR AN AMENDMENT TO amendment to the Special Use/Planned Unit
Development and to amend Ordinance O-06-56 for
regarding the number of students allowed and to
install a connection between the 1141 and 1181
buildings. The Plan Commission voted 5-1 in favor
Larry Friedman, attorney for BJBE, stated the
original special use PUD had a discrepancy in the
number of students that would be present during the
week; therefore, they are asking for a clarification. The second portion of the request would add
225 students for Sunday religious school instead of holding classes off-sight at Caruso. Mr.
Friedman stated the third part of their request would remove a door between the two buildings.
Mr. Friedman indicated the school performed a traffic and parking study and found there would
not be a negative impact on parking or traffic. They are also working with the Chicagoland
Jewish High School on accommodations to use their turnaround and parking. Trustee Struthers
questioned the number of parking spaces available on site. Dan Brinkman, traffic engineer with
Gewalt Hamilton Associates, stated they have 272 spaces in the Deerfield Office Park and 179
spaces dedicated for the school. He noted they have an agreement for 40 additional spaces.
Trustee Struthers, who lives near Caruso, said the parking lot is full on Sundays. Mr. Brinkman
noted there are a number of activities at Caruso which lead people to park in the neighborhood.
Most of the time, however, they do not have that overflow parking issue. Trustee Struthers
indicated the congregation does good job directing traffic. Mr. Friedman believes it would be a
vast improvement to consolidate the congregation activities to the congregation site, instead of
Trustee Jester noted the Village will be looking at restricting vehicular traffic from going through
Pine Street. It was not allowed in the past, and he stated he will push for it to be restricted to just
left and right turns when the Lake Cook Road construction project is completed.
Trustee Seiden moved acceptance of the report and recommendation of the Plan Commission.
Trustee Benton seconded the motion. The motion passed by the following vote:
AYES: Benton, Jester, Nadler, Seiden, Struthers (5)
The Plan Commission held a Public Hearing on
April 11, 2013 consider a request to rezone the
REQUEST TO REZONE THE PROPERTY property at 780 Saunders Road from R-1 Single
Family Residential to C-2 Outlying Commercial
District for an amendment to the Comprehensive
Plan and a Special Use for a restaurant. The Plan
Commission voted 5-1 in favor of the request with
the condition of limiting the use to a restaurant or
The Board of Zoning Appeals held a Public Hearing
OF THE BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS on May 7, 2013 to consider a request to reduce the
minimum front and side yard setbacks to 7 feet
instead of the required 12 feet. The Plan
Commission voted 4-1 in favor of the request. The
Plan Commission considered the request to reduce
the required number of parking spaces from 35 to
33. The Plan Commission voted 5-0 in favor of the
The petitioners, Anil and Upasana Abbott, purchased the property in March 2012. They want to
build a restaurant on the property. Mrs. Abbott said the goal of Health O Wealth is to promote
healthy living through balanced nutrition. The restaurant will feature food that is low in
cholesterol, salt and sugar and high in greens, fiber and antioxidants. The food will be freshly
prepared with no preservatives. The restaurant will feature smoothies, herbal teas, soups and
sandwiches. They will also highlight organic, gluten-free, allergen-free and eco-friendly foods
Trustee Seiden inquired about the petitioner’s retail experience. Mr. Abbott stated he has more
than 25 years of experience in the retail food business.
Mayor Rosenthal expressed concern about the number of variations. She believes the space may
be too small to accommodate the business. She questioned what would happen to the building if
the business ceased operation. Mr. Coblentz stated the property would be zoned C-2 Outlying
Commercial. Mayor Rosenthal questioned why the Trustees would want to allow all the
variations. Trustee Jester stated the alternative is a single family home, which would be out of
Trustee Struthers noted there does not seem to be parking for carry out. Mr. Abbott stated the
employees of Parkway North would walk to the restaurant. He noted they would have additional
parking at the Mobile station for employees, as he owns that business as well. Mr. Abbott
indicated they would sign an agreement with the bank if additional parking is needed.
Trustees Benton and Nadler believe the restaurant would serve a purpose for the entire
neighborhood. Trustee Nadler added the restaurant would help clean up the site. Trustee
Struthers suggested making the building smaller to add additional parking. Mrs. Abbott stated
they wanted to have a separate, gluten-free kitchen, which would have to be removed if they
Mayor Rosenthal questioned the legal implication of having overflow parking at the bank and the
Mobile station. Mr. Coblentz noted the petitioner would have to have binding agreements or the
Trustee Benton moved acceptance of the report and recommendation of the Plan Commission
regarding the requests. Trustee Seiden seconded the motion. The motion passed by the
AYES: Benton, Jester, Nadler, Seiden, Struthers (5)
Trustee Seiden moved acceptance of the report and recommendation of the Board of Zoning
Appeals regarding the requests. Trustee Benton seconded the motion. The motion passed by the
AYES: Benton, Jester, Nadler, Seiden, Struthers (5)
REQUEST OF KEVIN AND CLAUDINE The Board of Zoning Appeals held a Public
HARIG OF 260 DEERFIELD ROAD FOR Hearing to consider the request for a variation that
A VARIATION THAT WOULD PERMIT would permit the construction of a two-story
addition extending 7 feet into the 50 foot minimum
rear yard. Mr. Street indicated the 1968 subdivision
FEET INTO THE 50’ MINIMUM REAR created the existing non-conformity. The Board of
Zoning Appeals voted 5-0 in favor of the request.
Trustee Jester moved acceptance of the report and recommendation of the Board of Zoning
Appeals regarding the request. Trustee Benton seconded the motion. The motion passed by the
AYES: Benton, Jester, Nadler, Seiden, Struthers (5)
(IEPA) requires a Village Ordinance for the
GROUNDWATER USE RESTRICTION property. The Limited Area Groundwater Ordinance
is in conformance with the requirements of the
IEPA. The supplemental agreement protects the
Village by providing indemnities. The Village’s environmental consultants support the
appropriateness of both Ordinances. First Reading.
An Ordinance Authorizing a Limited Area
GROUNDWATER USE RESTRICTION Road. The Ordinance is in conformance with
the requirements of the IEPA and is supported by
There were no items on the Consent Agenda.
ORDINANCE O-13-19 AUTHORIZING An Ordinance authorizing agreements with
Deerfield School District 109 for the regulation of
motor vehicle traffic and parking on school
Trustee Struthers noted this would allow the Police
Department to regulate traffic on school property.
Chief Sliozis noted the enforcement would be 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. He noted they
would install signage over the summer and start enforcement at the beginning of the new school
Trustee Benton moved approval of the Ordinance. Trustee Struthers seconded the motion. The
motion passed by the following vote:
AYES: Benton, Jester, Nadler, Seiden, Struthers (5)
An Ordinance authorizing a Text Amendment to the
temporary business sign regulations in the
commercial zoning districts to limit the maximum
size of a temporary ground sign. First Reading.
TO LIMIT THE MAXIMUM SIZE OF A
INTERGOVERNMENTAL AGREEMENT Library employees are required to park off site
when they move into the new facility. This
maintenance and ongoing energy costs. The Village
will contribute $85,000. The library and park
Trustee Seiden moved approval of the Intergovernmental Agreement. Trustee Struthers
seconded the motion. The motion passed by the following vote:
AYES: Benton, Jester, Nadler, Seiden, Struthers (5)
Director of Public Works and Engineering Barbara
Little stated the Village is looking at $25,000
in additional costs and $43,000 in credits for the
Project. This results in a credit of $17,983.
Trustee Struthers moved approval of WRF change order number 20. Trustee Benton seconded
the motion. The motion passed by the following vote:
AYES: Benton, Jester, Nadler, Seiden, Struthers (5)
Mayor Rosenthal noted the medical marijuana law
is awaiting Governor Quinn’s signature. The
proposed law allows one dispensary per state senate district. She recommended the Plan
Commission to study the law and prepare a recommendation.
Mayor Rosenthal, Mr. Street and Assistant to the
Village Manager Andrew Lichterman met with
representatives from ComEd to go over the 2012 report. The Village is much improved from
2011. Mayor Rosenthal indicated the work required as a result of the lawsuit has been
completed. Mayor Rosenthal suggested residents get the ComEd application on their smart
phones to stay informed in the event of a power outage.
Mayor Rosenthal reported the Illinois House and
Senate passed the concealed carry law. It has not
yet been signed by Governor Quinn. As a home rule community, Deerfield has the option to ban
assault weapons in the Village, however no such ordinance could be approved after 10 days of
the Governor signing the bill. This gives the Village a short window of time to take action, if
they wish to do so. Mayor Rosenthal asked that this item be added to the June 17, 2013, Board of
Trustees agenda. The Village currently has an Ordinance on handgun control. Trustee Seiden
asked what would happen in the Governor signed the bill tomorrow. Mr. Coblentz noted the
Board could hold a special meeting. Trustee Jester noted the Village currently has regulations in
place. He questioned whether the new law would supersede the Village’s ordinance. Mr.
Coblentz stated the bill includes a preemption of Home Rule authority on assault weapons.
Chief Sliozis added that the Village’s current ordinance does not have a specific ban on assault
weapons. He noted the proposed bill is quite lengthy and staff and the Village Attorney will be
Mayor Rosenthal informed residents that the
American Legion’s flag retirement ceremony would
take place at 6:30 pm on June 12, 2013, at the Jewett Park Pavilion.
Mayor Rosenthal thanked the Fine Arts Committee
and the DBR Chamber of Commerce for putting on
the Fine Arts Festival this weekend. The artists were great and the restaurants were very happy.
She also thanked the police department and public works staff for all their assistance with the
The traveling exhibit of the United Holocaust
Museum will hold an event on June 9, 2013, from
10 a.m. – 5 p.m. at the Sheraton in Chicago.
Trustee Nadler congratulated the Deerfield High
School boys’ volleyball team for winning
sectionals. The Lacrosse team got to the semi-finals, as well.
There being no further business or discussion,
Trustee Benton made a motion to adjourn the
meeting. Trustee Jester seconded the motion. The motion passed unanimously. The meeting was

The payment of the above listed accounts has been approved
by the Board of Trustees at their meeting held on June 17, 2013 and
you are hereby authorized to pay them from the appropriate funds.
Report on Assault Weapons Ban and HB183 Firearm Concealed Carry Act

text.b: Summary of Background and Reason for Request

page.text: Pursuant to HB 183, home-rule communities, such as Deerfield, are allowed to consider the ban of
“assault weapons” within 10 days of enactment. Attorney Coblentz has prepared a memorandum further
Deerfield Contact Us - Mayor Harriet Rosenthal
Comment: I just read today about the mayor's pledge to ban "assault rifles"
First I would like the know what the point is, since we have never had crimes
in Deerfield commited with an assault rifle? Is she just trying to suck up to
Rahm and Bloomberg? You are our mayor? Not that useless city called Chicago
2nd, Does the mayor even know what an assault rifle is? Or does she just
choose them by what is acary. Let her know an assault rifle is a selective
fire rifle able to go from semi-auto to full auto with a lever or switch. This
is how the army see it, which is the foremost authority on weaponry in the US,
3rd Is the mayor really looking that badly for things to do that she has to
pass laws that will have no benefit to Deerfield residents and instead will
alienate ones who may have these types of rifles she thinks are "scary"
I am deeply concerned with passing laws to not help our citizens and instead
to appear as more political posturing and sucking up to horrible leaders in
other cities like Bloomberg and Rahm Emanual.
----- Forwarded by David E. Fitzgerald/Administration/Deerfield on 06/05/2013 09:35 AM -----
Please consider the Wilson case while deciding to pass an assault weapon ban. The Illinois
Supreme court has sent this issue back 3 times and is now in discovery.
Save the city of Deerfield lawsuit money by not passing this law that will affect only the law
abiding. Please reply with statistics specific to Deerfield proving a need for this law in Deerfield.
An Independent Agent of Protravel Network
----- Forwarded by David E. Fitzgerald/Administration/Deerfield on 06/05/2013 09:35 AM -----
My name is Alan Kaufman, I am an attorney and Deerfield resident. I am emailing to voice my
vigorous objections to any new gun laws, including any proposed "assault weapon" bans.
The mayor recently stated that she can't think of one reason to own an assault weapon. Well, I
live in Deerfield and I own one and would be more than happy to discuss it with her. I own a
semi automatic shotgun, I use it to shoot trap and skeet.
The inherent problem with assault weapon bans is that the politicians drafting these laws don't
understand firearms. The only difference between a traditional hunting rifle or shotgun is their
appearance. Assault weapons are not machine guns, they simply have the appearance of being
According to the FBI crime data, a person was more likely to be murdered with a hammer than a
rifle, of all descriptions. Deerfield has had one murder in the past 13 years and as far as I can tell
a rifle or shotgun has never been used in a crime in Deerfield.
An assault weapon ban is a solution looking for a problem. It will result in more litigation, which
I don't want my tax dollars paying for. Take a lesson from Oak Park and Chicago. The NRA is
winning awards in the millions of dollars by suing foolish villages and cities.
Public Hearing to Consider a Proposed Annexation Agreement in Regards to
the Proposed Annexation to the Village of Deerfield, Illinois, of a Tract of
Property Comprising Approximately 7.68 acres of Land Formerly Known as
the Beth Or Synagogue and Surrounding Properties, Which Are Generally
Located West of the Tollway, South of Deerfield Road, and North and East of
the Existing Parkway North Center Office Development

text.b: Summary of Background and Reason for Request:

page.text: The petitioners are requesting annexation of 7.68 acres of land formerly known as the Beth
Or Synagogue and surrounding properties, which are generally located west of the
Tollway, south of Deerfield Road, and north and east of the Existing Parkway North Center
Office Development. It is proposed that the subject property be zoned as a Residential
Planned Unit Development in the R-5 General Residence District providing for the
development of mid-rise apartment buildings containing approximately 260 dwelling units,
recreational facilities and open space, all in accordance with the annexation agreement.
The petitioner has submitted materials regarding private open recreational space credit
and building permit fee comparisons. These materials are still under review by staff.
This ANNEXATION AGREEMENT (WOODVIEW RESIDENCES AT PARKWAY
NORTH) (this “Agreement”) is made and entered into as of this ____ day of ______________,
2013, by and between the VILLAGE OF DEERFIELD, ILLINOIS, a municipal corporation (the
“Village”), by and through its President and Board of Trustees (collectively, the “Corporate
Authorities”) and WOODVIEW APARTMENTS LLC, a(n) ______________ limited liability
company [ENTITY NAME TO BE CONFIRMED] (the “Developer”) (the Village, Corporate
Authorities and Developer are sometimes referred to herein collectively as the “Parties” and
WHEREAS, the Developer is the owner of record of an approximately 7.68-acre tract of
real estate generally located south of Deerfield Road on the west side of the Tri-State Tollway in
Lake County, Illinois, which real estate is legally described on the Plat of Annexation which is
attached hereto and made a part hereof as Exhibit A (the “Property”); and
WHEREAS, the Property is not situated within the limits of any municipality, but is
WHEREAS, the Developer desires and proposes to annex the Property to the Village and
to develop (or cause to be developed) the Property upon certain terms and conditions hereinafter

text.i: This space reserved for Recorder’s use only.

page.text: set forth and in accordance with [REFERENCE TO DEVELOPMENT PLANS TO BE
INSERTED] which are attached hereto and made a part hereof as Exhibit B (the “Plans”); and
WHEREAS, the Plans contemplate development of the Property with an approximately
four-story multi-family residential building, with an interior courtyard and including
approximately 260 apartment units and enclosed and unenclosed on-site parking; and
WHEREAS, the Developer has submitted an application to the Village seeking to have
the property zoned as R-5 General Residence District and for approval of a Special Use Planned
Unit Development of the Property, including modifications, as necessary to permit the
development of the Property in accordance with the Plans; and
WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities, after due and careful consideration, have
concluded that the annexation of the Property to the Village, on the terms and conditions
hereinafter set forth, and the unified development of the Property, as provided herein, would
further the growth of the Village, increase its tax assessable values, enable the Village to control
the development of the Property and would be in the best interests of the Village; and
WHEREAS, pursuant to the provisions of Section 11-15.1-1, et seq. of the Illinois
Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-15.1-1), a a public hearing was held on this Annexation
Agreement before the corporate authorities of the Village on June 17, 2013 pursuant to notice as
provided by statute and ordinance; and
WHEREAS, pursuant to notice as required by statute and ordinance, a public hearing has
been held by the Village Plan Commission with regard to the re-zoning of the Property and the
approval of a Special Use Planned Unit Development, including modifications, necessary to
implement the Plans, and the Village Plan Commission has submitted its recommendations of
approval of the aforesaid requests to the Corporate Authorities; and
WHEREAS, pursuant to the provisions of Section 7-1-8 of the Illinois Municipal Code
(65 ILCS 5/7-1-8) a proper petition for annexation was filed with the Clerk of the Village; and
WHEREAS, [TBD – NOTICE TO FIRE PROTECTION DISTRICT AND
LIBRARY DISTRICT REQUIRED IN THIS CASE?]; and
WHEREAS, due and timely notice of the proposed annexation was given to the West
Deerfield Township Highway Commissioner and the Board of Town Trustees, the West
Deerfield Township Supervisor and the West Deerfield Township Clerk, in the manner and form
WHEREAS, the Village, after due and careful consideration, has concluded that the
annexation, zoning and development of the Property pursuant to the terms and conditions
hereinafter set forth would further the growth of the Village, enable to Village to control the
development of the area, increase the taxable value of property within the Village, extend the
corporate limits and jurisdiction of the Village, permit the sound planning and development of
the Village and otherwise enhance and promote the general welfare of the Village and its
NOW THEREFORE, in consideration of the premises and of the mutual covenants and
agreements herein contained, it is hereby agreed by and between the Parties as follows:
The above and foregoing recitals, being true and material to this
Agreement, are hereby incorporated into this Agreement as if fully set forth herein.
This Agreement is made pursuant to and in accordance with
provisions of Section 11-15.1-1, et seq. of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-15.1-1, et
The Developer has filed proper petitions for annexation
with the Village Clerk to annex the Property to the Village.
Immediately upon the occurrence of all of
the execution of this Agreement by the Village and the Developer [PLACEHOLDER FOR
ANY OTHER ANCILLARY AGREEMENTS, AS APPLICABLE], the Corporate
Authorities shall enact a valid and binding ordinance (the “Annexation Ordinance”) annexing the
Property to the Village. Said Annexation Ordinance will be recorded with the Lake County
Recorder’s Office along with the Plat of Annexation within 30 days after enactment of the
Immediately upon the passage of the Annexation
Ordinance, the Corporate Authorities shall adopt an ordinance or ordinances (the “Rezoning
Ordinances”) which shall (i) rezone the Property to the R-5 General Residence District (the “R-5
District”); (ii) approve a Special Use for Planned Unit Development, including certain
exceptions and modifications from the Village Zoning Ordinance to allow development of the
Property in accordance with the Plans; and (iii) approve an amendment to the Parkway North
Center Planned Unit Development to allow (subject to appropriate agreements, easements or
other rights to be secured by Developer from private property owners) road access, an overlook
at the retention pond, and a combined retention area, consistent with the Plans.
The Village hereby approves the Plans for the project described
herein and also specifically approves the Preliminary Development Plan, as defined in Section
12.09-C of the Village Zoning Ordinance. The Village agrees to approve Final Development
Plans, as defined in Section 12.09-F of the Village Zoning Ordinance, including adopting such
ordinance or ordinances approving such Final Development Plans and authorizing any other
action necessary to implement such Final Development Plans, provided such Final Development
Plans substantially conform to the previously approved Preliminary Development Plan. The
Plans contemplate the following exceptions and modifications from the terms of the Village
Zoning Ordinance (exceptions and modifications noted in bold typeface):

text.b: (57 feet to top of elevator room deck)
45 FT in most areas; 20/30 FT at
overlook in north and east setback

page.text: The Developer retains the right, in accordance with the Planned Unit Development provisions of
the Village’s Zoning Ordinance, to seek to amend the Plans, the approved Preliminary
Development Plan and the approved Final Development Plans. The Village will expeditiously
process such request in accordance with its Planned Unit Development procedures.7
[RELIEF NEEDED FOR SIGNS]8 Proposed Roadway Improvements. The Developer
shall construct a private access road in substantial conformance to the Plans and in accordance
with Final Development Plans and Development Agreement approved by Village, to provide
primary access off existing Parkway North Boulevard at the southwest corner of the Property. A
new traffic signal will be installed at no cost to the Village at the intersection of Parkway North
Boulevard and Deerfield Road by Developer and/or Parkway North property owners. Additional
emergency access will be provided via a new limited-access private drive on the west side of the
Property connected to existing Deer Run Drive. [INSERT PROVISIONS REGARDING
DEER RUN DRIVE – VACATION AND DEDICATION]9.
Developer shall have the right to connect to the Village’s water system at the existing 12” water
main located within Parkway North Boulevard, subject to execution of appropriate agreements
with private property owners, as may be required for the Property to connect at this location.
Alternatively, the Developer may elect to connect to the Village’s water system at the existing
12” water main located within the Deerfield Road right-of-way; provided, however, that the
Developer shall be responsible for extending said Deerfield Road water main to the point of
The Developer intends to connect to the
Lake County Public Work Department’s (“LCPW”) sanitary sewer system. The Corporate
Authorities agree to cooperate with the Developer and use reasonable efforts to aid the
Developer in obtaining such permits from the LCPW and any other governmental agencies
having jurisdiction as may be necessary to authorize connections from the Property to such sewer
Storm Sewer and Storm water Retention.
The Developer, at its expense, shall,
subject to the approval of the Village Engineer and all other governmental bodies having
jurisdiction, and subject to appropriate agreements, easements or other rights to be secured by
Developer from private property owners, construct the on-site storm sewers and appurtenances
serving the Property and the expended retention pond, all as depicted in the Plans. 12.
Easements Required for Development Plan. It shall be the responsibility of Developer, at
its sole expense, to obtain any easements, access or property rights required to implement the
Dedication of Streets and Utilities and Vacation of Streets. No streets (except for Deer
Run Drive, if Developer makes the election referenced in Section 8 above), water mains (except
for the extended Deerfield Road water main, if Developer makes the election referenced in
Section 8 above), sanitary sewers, storm sewers or other utilities located on the Property shall be
dedicated to the Village.14. Park, School, Fire Protection, Village and Library Impact Fees;
Credit. Pursuant to Ordinance 0-93-48, the Developer shall receive a park impact fee credit for
private open spaces and recreation areas and facilities provided as part of the project, as
described in the Plans, the Rezoning Ordinances and the Preliminary Development Plan, and
shall provide cash contributions for improvement of existing school, park, fire protection, village
and library sites as provided in Exhibit __ attached hereto.15.
Developer shall pay to the Village building permit fees as and when required under generally-
applicable Village laws; provided however, such building permit fees shall not exceed the
amount calculated according to the following: 16. Deerfield Park District.
agrees to execute any necessary and appropriate legal documents to annex to the Deerfield Park
District any portions of the Property which are not presently within the corporate limits of
another park district and which otherwise conform to any applicable state or municipal
as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement, the Rezoning Ordinances, the approved
Preliminary Development Plan and any approved Final Development Plans, all aspects of the
development of the project herein proposed, including the construction of buildings, facilities or
other improvements, and the use of the Property, shall comply with all applicable Village
ordinances, codes and regulations. All ordinances of the Village relating to zoning, subdivision
control, building, and related ordinances in effect as of the date hereof, shall insofar as they may
apply to the Property, continue in effect during the full term of this Agreement, with the
exception of amendments updating the Village’s building ordinances and other related technical
Facilitation of Development. Time is of the essence of this
Agreement, and all Parties will make every reasonable effort to expedite the subject matters
hereof. It is further understood and agreed by the Parties that the successful consummation and
performance of this Agreement and the development of the Property in the best interests of all
the Parties requires their continued cooperation, and the Parties do hereby agree to provide such
Agreement, the Party claiming such breach, in any court of competent jurisdiction, by an
appropriate action or proceeding at law or in equity, secure specific performance of the
covenants and agreements herein contained, be awarded damages for failure of performance or
both, or obtain rescission and disconnection for repudiation or material failure of performance.
If any provision of this Agreement is held invalid, such provision shall be deemed to be excised
herefrom and the invalidity thereof shall not affect any of the other provisions contained herein.
Before any failure of any Party to this Agreement to perform its obligations under this
Agreement shall be deemed to be a breach of this Agreement, the party claiming such failure
shall notify, in writing, the Party alleged to have failed to perform the alleged failure and demand
performance. No breach of this Agreement may be found to have occurred if performance has
been commenced to the satisfaction of the complaining Party within twenty-one (21) days of the
receipt of such notice.The failure of any Party to this Agreement to insist upon the strict and
prompt performance of the terms, covenants, agreements, and conditions herein contained, or
any of them, upon any other Party imposed, shall not constitute or be construed as a waiver or
relinquishment of any Party’s right thereafter to enforce any such term, covenant, agreement or
condition, but the same shall continue in full force and effect. No action taken by any Party to
this Agreement shall be deemed to constitute an election of remedies and all remedies set forth in
this Agreement shall be cumulative and non-exclusive of any other remedy either set forth herein
or available to any Party at law or equity.
Amendments. The Parties agree that this Agreement and any exhibits attached hereto
may be amended by the mutual consent of the Parties hereto by the adoption of an ordinance of
the Village authorizing the execution of such amendment, after a public hearing in accordance
with Article 11, Division 15.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-15.1-1 et. seq.) and
the execution of said amendment by the parties or their successors in interest.21. Prior
Agreements. Except as expressly provided herein, this Agreement supercedes all prior
agreements, negotiations and exhibits and is a full integration of the entire agreement of the
This Agreement will be binding on the Parties and
their respective successors and assigns for a term of twenty (20) years, commencing as of the
date set forth above, and for such further term as may hereafter be authorized by statute or
ordinance of the Village. Nothing herein shall in any way prevent the alienation or sale of the
Property, or any portion thereof, except that said sale shall be subject to the provisions hereof,
and any successor owner shall be benefited and bound by the conditions and restrictions herein
expressed.23. Severability. If any provision, covenant, agreement or portion of this Agreement
or its application to any person, entity or property is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect
the application or validity of any other provisions, covenants or portions of this agreement and,
to that end, any provision, covenants, agreements or portions of this Agreement are declared to
Any notice required pursuant to the provisions of this
Agreement shall be in writing and shall be deemed effectively given on (i) the date of personal
delivery, or (ii) on the first business day following deposit with a recognized national overnight
courier service, or (iii) on the second business day following deposit in the U.S. mail, certified or
registered, return receipt requested, postage prepaid, to the Parties at the following addresses, or
at such other addresses as the Parties may, by notice, designate:
Attn: Peter Coblentz, Esq.25. Counterparts. This Agreement may be
executed in any number of counterparts each of which shall be deemed an original, but all of
which, taken together, shall constitute one and the same instrument.26.
Wherever any approval or consent of the Village, or of any of its departments, officials,
employees, attorneys or consultants is called for under this Agreement, the same shall not be
Interpretation. The Village and Developer have
each had the advice of counsel in the negotiation of this Agreement and no other provision of
this Agreement shall be construed against a Party or its counsel because such counsel may have
had primary responsibility for the drafting thereof.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Village and the Developer have caused this instrument to
be executed by their respective proper officials duly authorized to execute the same as of the day
and the year first above written.
Title: President of the Board of Trustees
I, the undersigned, a notary public in and for the County and State aforesaid, DO
HEREBY CERTIFY THAT ________________, personally known to me to be the President of
the Board of Trustees of the Village of Deerfield, an Illinois municipal corporation (the
“Village”), and _________________, personally known to me to be the Village Clerk of said
Village, and personally known to me to be the same persons whose names are subscribed to the
foregoing instrument, appeared before me this day in person and severally acknowledged that as
such President and Village Clerk, they signed and delivered the said instrument as said President
and Village Clerk, and caused the corporate seal of said Village to be affixed thereto, pursuant to
authority given by the Board of Trustees of said Village, as their free and voluntary act, and as
the free and voluntary act and deed of said Village, for the uses and purposes therein set forth.
GIVEN under my hand and notarial seal this ____ day of ____________, 2013.
I, the undersigned, a notary public in and for the County and State aforesaid, DO
HEREBY CERTIFY THAT ________________, personally known to me to be the
_______________ of Ravine Park Partners, LLC (the “Company”), and personally known to me
to be the same person whose name is subscribed to the foregoing instrument, appeared before me
this day in person and acknowledged that as such ___________ of the Company, s/he signed and
delivered the said instrument as said ___________, pursuant to authority given by the Company,
as his/her free and voluntary act, and as the free and voluntary act and deed of said Company, for
the uses and purposes therein set forth.
GIVEN under my hand and notarial seal this ____ day of ____________, 2013.
Report and Recommendation of the Plan Commission re: Request for
Annexation; an Amendment to Comprehensive Plan; Rezoning; and a
Preliminary Residential PUD to Permit the Woodview Apartment
Development, Including an Amendment to the Parkway North Center PUD to

text.b: Summary of Background and Reason for Request:

page.text: The petitioners are requesting approval for annexation; an amendment to comprehensive
plan; rezoning; and a preliminary residential Planned Unit Development to permit the
proposed 260-unit Woodview apartment development. The petitioners are also requesting
an amendment to the Parkway North Center Planned Unit Development to accommodate
PUD Required Findings and Rezoning Standards
TO: Mayor and Board of Trustees
RE: Public hearing on the request for annexation; an amendment to Comprehensive
Plan; rezoning; and a preliminary residential planned unit development with the
requested variations to permit the Woodview luxury apartment development on the
former Beth Or and surrounding residential parcels (unincorporated properties
southwest of the intersection of the Tri-State Tollway and Deerfield Road), including an
amendment to the Parkway North Center Planned Unit Development to allow changes
on the Parkway North Center property to accommodate the proposed Woodview
We transmit for your consideration a recommendation adopted by the Plan Commission
of the Village of Deerfield on the request of the petitioners for annexation; an
amendment to Comprehensive Plan; rezoning; and a preliminary residential planned
unit development with the requested variations to permit the Woodview luxury
apartment development on the former Beth Or and surrounding residential parcels
(unincorporated properties southwest of the intersection of the Tri-State Tollway and
Deerfield Road), including an amendment to the Parkway North Center Planned Unit
Development to allow changes on the Parkway North Center property to accommodate
The Plan Commission held a public hearing on
May 23, 2013. At that public hearing, the petitioners presented testimony and
documentary evidence in support of the request. A copy of the public hearing and
In support of its request, the Plan Commission makes the following findings of fact and
The subject properties consist of the 7.68 acres of unincorporated land located between
the Tollway on the east, Deerfield Road on the north, and Parkway North Center on the
west and south. The subject properties are zoned R-1 Residential District in
unincorporated Lake County. The subject properties currently consist of the former
Beth Or synagogue and the surrounding parcels as shown on the petitioners’ plans
which outline the subject property. The petition also involves the Parkway North Center
PUD, as several of the proposed improvements take place on the Parkway North
The two properties to the northeast of the subject property are single family homes
located in unincorporated Lake County and will remain unincorporated with vehicular
access coming from the existing Deer Run Drive which is a frontage road that connects

text.b: Surrounding Land Use and Zoning for Woodview Parcels

page.text: North (across Deerfield Road): Unincorporated R-1 Residential District – Tollway on-
ramp; Village of Riverwoods - Deerfield Park District Golf Course
South and West: I-1 Office Research and Restricted Industry District – Parkway North
Center – office buildings and Marriott Suites Hotel
East: Tollway, and across the Tollway is I-1 Office Research and Restricted Industry
The petitioners are proposing to develop the property with a multi-family luxury
apartment building. The development will be known as Woodview Apartments. The
petitioners are proposing a 4-story building with an interior amenity courtyard. A total of
260 units are proposed for the 7.68 acre site which results in a density of 34.89 units
per acre (260 units / 7.68 acres = 33.85 units per acre). The apartment units will range
from studios to 3 bedrooms, the smallest unit being 550 square feet and the largest unit
being 1,200 square feet, with the average unit size of 893 square feet. The petitioner’s
materials include floor plans for each level. Some first floor units will have outdoor
garden patios. The petitioners have indicated the interiors will include high quality
finishes. The building will feature a clubhouse which contains a fitness center, bike
shop, and lounge/kitchen. Outdoor amenities will include a courtyard, a pool, a
community garden, a wood deck overlook, pedestrian paths, and an outdoor dog
park/dog run. The petitioners have indicated that they will be seeking Leadership in
Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) certification for the project. The attached
aerial photos show the site of the proposed Woodview 4-story residential building, and
the surrounding Parkway North Center office buildings, including one 3-story building,
one 4-story building, and two 5-story buildings, as well as the two single family homes
The petitioners’ materials indicate their target market is young professionals and empty
nesters. The petitioners’ materials indicate the average rental rates will be between
$1,225 and $2,500 per month, and households with incomes as low as $44,000 will
qualify to rent there. Their materials indicate that nearly 60 percent of Woodview’s
residences will be affordable to those making less than $62,000 per year. The
petitioners believe that their proposed luxury apartment building will be attractive to
young professional workers in the area and will also be a benefit to local employers. As
part of their submittal package the petitioners have provided a market study and a fiscal
The building elevation drawings show that the building façade will consist of masonry
recessed walls and wood siding walls, aluminum window systems with dark wood
frames, and light grey accent panels. The building will be 50’ in height to the top of the
coping on the parapet walls, with the building’s roof deck at 45’. The building will
contain an internal 5-story open roof parking structure (parking is available on all five
levels). The parking structure itself will be 45’ in height and will be surrounded by a
parapet wall reaching a height of 50’. The tallest point on the structure will be the top of
the mechanical/elevator penthouse at 57’ in height. The parking structure will contain
365 parking spaces and the site will have 25 outdoor ground-level parking spaces (6
parallel parking spaces to the south of the building, and nineteen 90-degree parking
spaces to the north of the building), for a total of 390 parking spaces in this apartment
Currently, there is a retention pond located to the east of the apartment building which
serves the Parkway North Center property. The petitioners will be connecting with the
existing retention pond for Parkway North Center and expanding it further north so that
is can also serve the proposed apartment development.
The petitioners’ materials include a detailed landscaping plan. Shade trees will be
planted along the private roads on the south and west sides of the property. Trees and
landscaping will be provided around the perimeter of the building. There will be a
community garden and a sand volleyball court on the north side of the building. The
petitioners have indicated that the site will be pedestrian and bicycle friendly. Walking
paths with benches will be installed in the development and around the proposed
Woodview property and the paths connect to Parkway North’s existing walking paths. A
wood overlook deck will be provided by the retention pond. The overlook extends onto
the Parkway North Center property. The main entrance off Parkway North Boulevard
will include a lawn with a water feature and a Gabion screen wall backed by ornamental
trees. Entry signage will be located near the main entrance off Parkway North
The petitioners have provided a traffic impact study conducted by V3. Pages 4 through
7 of the report describe the existing roadway conditions and traffic volumes on nearby
roadways. The busiest periods for traffic are from 7 to 9 a.m. and from 4 to 6 p.m., with
7:45 to 8:45 a.m. and 4:45 to 5:45 p.m. being the peak hours. Figure 5 on page 8
shows the existing peak traffic volumes. The chart on page 9 indicates the projected
traffic volumes generated by the proposed Woodview development, and Figure 6 on
page 11 shows the projected directional distribution of the traffic generated by the
Woodview development. Figure 8 on page 13 shows the projected traffic volumes for
the year 2019, which includes both traffic generated by the proposed Woodview
apartment development and traffic that would otherwise be using the roads.
